awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Integrating Cognitive and Computer Science to Improve Cyber Security: Selective Attention and Personality Traits for the Detection and Prevention of Risk
awd_abstract_narration: Increasingly, there is a need for better understanding of behavioral and cognitive factors in cyber security. This project is a novel collaboration between computer science cyber security researchers and a cognitive science researcher to generate data on the links between personality traits and cyber security. The broad theoretical premise of the proposed research is that there are particular cognitive preferences and related personality factors that can be assessed in real time, real world scenarios and these may be associated with individual user's secure/insecure cyber behavior. The personality characteristics of trait anxiety and callous unemotional traits are tested via innovative software architecture for immersing subjects in realistic cyber scenarios, to examine the links between response latencies for certain stimuli, personality factors, and cyber behaviors. By studying the links between personality traits and cyber behaviors, it may be possible to develop adaptive software systems, such as user interfaces, alerting systems, and security monitors that tap individual stimuli preferences to substantially reduce the risks or effects of cyber-attacks. The data from the study will inform future work in adaptive cyber security mechanisms, better tailored to individual user traits. The research potentially impacts all sectors of society, since individual citizens, as well as the law enforcement, military, and corporate communities all benefit from research efforts that could facilitate development of better cyber security methods. Furthermore, the psychology and cyber security research communities will benefit from the results of this project and the developed software architecture.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The main contribution of this work is two-fold: First is the development of SPICE (Software Package for Investigating Computer Experiences), which is a flexible, scriptable software architecture for conducting experiments to explore the relationships between individual personality traits and cyber behavior. Second is the pilot studies of these relationships on human subjects using SPICE. SPICE and the collected data are publicly available for use by the research community and their details are published in peer-reviewed conferences and journals. In a nutshell, the data analysis shows that secure cyber actions are common among end-users, however, insecure actions are less common – with a few extreme outliers.  The research on the subject is particularly useful to adapt software interfaces, warnings, and messages in accordance with personality traits to improve the security posture of end users. The project supported two graduate students in cybersecurity and psychology, enhancing the workforce of knowledgeable cybersecurity specialists in an interdisciplinary domain. 

Overall, we performed three major tasks to conduct the pilot studies.

First, we conducted a pilot testing on subjects completed the self-report items (refer to as iSECURE ) and accomplished (1) examining the incidence and distributions of self-report items to assess secure and insecure behavior, (2) provide psychometric analysis and refinement of the self-report through factor analysis secure and insecure cyber behaviors (e.g., susceptibility to cyber threat, propensity to insider attacks, and malicious hacking) and (3) tested the links between standard personality tests and secure and insecure behavior for the self-report measure. 

Second, we developed a new, easily configurable, and flexible software SPICE for psychologist and cognitive scientists to study personality traits and insecure cyber behavior of end users. The software utilizes well-established cognitive methods (such as dot-probe) to identify a number of personality traits, and further allows researchers to design and conduct experiments and detailed quantitative study on the cyber behavior of end users in a graphical based environment. The software collects fine-grained data on users for analysis.

Third, We utilized SPICE and collected data from a total of at least 140-150 individuals and develop final scoring for Susceptibility and Resilience to Cyber Threat (SRCT). The most salient finding is that the SCRTsecure and SCRTinsecure scales were significantly negatively correlated suggesting that those who made secure responses were less likely to make insecure responses. Correlations between the iSECURE and SRCT scales were not significant for the insecure scales, but the secure scales were negatively correlated, suggesting self-report of secure behaviors actually overestimates secure actions in the SCRT. 


Last Modified: 05/24/2018
Modified by: Irfan Ahmed
